events.title: First Olympic Games
events.description: The first recorded Olympic Games are held in Olympia, establishing the four-year cycle of the ancient Olympics.

events.title: Greek Colonization Begins
events.description: Greeks begin establishing colonies throughout the Mediterranean, spreading Greek culture and trade.

events.title: Homer's Epics Composed
events.description: Homer composes the Iliad and Odyssey, foundational works of Western literature that preserve the oral tradition of the Trojan War and its aftermath.

events.title: Rise of Tyrants
events.description: Tyrants begin to seize power in various Greek city-states, challenging aristocratic rule.

events.title: Solon's Reforms
events.description: Solon institutes major political and economic reforms in Athens, laying the foundation for democracy.

events.title: Cleisthenes Establishes Democracy
events.description: Cleisthenes reforms the Athenian constitution, establishing the world's first democratic government.

events.title: Battle of Marathon
events.description: Athenian forces defeat the Persians at Marathon, a decisive victory in the First Persian War.

events.title: Battle of Thermopylae
events.description: A small Greek force led by King Leonidas of Sparta makes a heroic stand against the Persian army.

events.title: Battle of Salamis
events.description: The Greek navy defeats the Persian fleet at Salamis, turning the tide of the Persian Wars.

events.title: Battles of Plataea and Mycale
events.description: Greek forces decisively defeat the Persians, ending the Persian invasion of Greece.

events.title: Parthenon Construction Begins
events.description: Construction begins on the Parthenon, the magnificent temple dedicated to Athena on the Acropolis, symbolizing the height of Athenian power and artistic achievement.

events.title: Herodotus Writes Histories
events.description: Herodotus completes his Histories, earning him the title 'Father of History' for his systematic investigation of the Greco-Persian Wars and the cultures of the ancient world.

events.title: Sophocles' Oedipus Rex
events.description: Sophocles writes Oedipus Rex, one of the greatest tragedies of ancient Greek drama, exemplifying the golden age of Athenian theater.

events.title: Euripides' Medea
events.description: Euripides writes Medea, showcasing his innovative approach to tragedy and psychological depth in Greek drama.

events.title: First Peloponnesian War Begins
events.description: Conflict breaks out between Athens and Sparta, beginning decades of warfare between the two powers.

events.title: Peloponnesian War Begins
events.description: The great war between Athens and Sparta begins, lasting 27 years and ending Athenian dominance.

events.title: Plague of Athens
events.description: A devastating plague strikes Athens during the Peloponnesian War, killing thousands including Pericles.

events.title: Athens Surrenders
events.description: Athens surrenders to Sparta, ending the Peloponnesian War and beginning Spartan hegemony.

events.title: Thucydides' History of the Peloponnesian War
events.description: Thucydides completes his History of the Peloponnesian War, establishing rigorous standards for historical writing and political analysis.

events.title: Trial and Death of Socrates
events.description: Socrates is tried and executed for corrupting the youth and impiety, becoming a martyr for philosophy.

events.title: Plato Founds the Academy
events.description: Plato establishes the Academy in Athens, the first institution of higher learning in the Western world, where he teaches philosophy and mathematics.

events.title: Battle of Leuctra
events.description: Thebes defeats Sparta at Leuctra, ending Spartan military dominance and beginning Theban hegemony.

events.title: Philip II Becomes King of Macedon
events.description: Philip II becomes king and begins transforming Macedon into a major military power.

events.title: Battle of Chaeronea
events.description: Philip II of Macedon defeats the combined forces of Athens and Thebes, establishing Macedonian dominance over Greece.

events.title: Aristotle Founds the Lyceum
events.description: Aristotle establishes the Lyceum in Athens, where he teaches and conducts research, creating a comprehensive system of philosophy and science.

events.title: Alexander the Great Becomes King
events.description: Alexander succeeds his father Philip II and begins his legendary conquests across Asia.

events.title: Alexander Invades Persia
events.description: Alexander begins his invasion of the Persian Empire, winning decisive victories at Granicus and Issus.

events.title: Battle of Gaugamela
events.description: Alexander defeats Darius III at Gaugamela, effectively ending the Persian Empire.

events.title: Alexandria Founded
events.description: Alexander the Great founds the city of Alexandria in Egypt, which becomes a major center of Hellenistic culture, learning, and commerce.

events.title: Alexander Invades India
events.description: Alexander leads his army into India, reaching the furthest extent of his conquests.

events.title: Death of Alexander the Great
events.description: Alexander dies in Babylon at age 32, leaving his vast empire to be divided among his generals.

events.title: Death of Aristotle
events.description: Aristotle, one of the greatest philosophers in history, dies, leaving behind a vast body of work.

events.title: Battle of Ipsus
events.description: The successors of Alexander fight at Ipsus, leading to the final division of his empire.

events.title: Euclid Writes Elements
events.description: Euclid compiles Elements, a comprehensive treatise on geometry and mathematics that becomes the standard textbook for over two millennia.

events.title: Library of Alexandria Founded
events.description: Ptolemy II establishes the Library of Alexandria, the largest library of the ancient world, becoming a center of scholarship and preserving countless works of literature and science.

events.title: Archimedes Born
events.description: Archimedes is born in Syracuse, later becoming one of the greatest mathematicians and inventors of antiquity, known for his work on geometry, mechanics, and hydrostatics.

events.title: Eratosthenes Born
events.description: Eratosthenes is born, later becoming the chief librarian of Alexandria and calculating the Earth's circumference with remarkable accuracy.

events.title: Death of Archimedes
events.description: Archimedes is killed during the Roman siege of Syracuse, ending the life of one of history's greatest mathematicians and inventors.

events.title: Roman Conquest of Greece
events.description: Rome defeats the Achaean League and sacks Corinth, completing the conquest of Greece and ending Greek independence.

events.title: Sulla Sacks Athens
events.description: Roman general Sulla sacks Athens during the First Mithridatic War, ending the city's golden age.
